topics.title: Fuel and engine framing for marketing
topics.summary: Emily reframes marketing as two parts: "fuel" (the valuable things you create like messaging, content, design) and an "engine" (distribution, tracking, ops). She explains the core diagnostic: identify whether growth is constrained by fuel or engine.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the show and Emily Kramer’s background building marketing teams at Asana, Carta, Ticketfly, and Astro, plus what listeners will learn. Sponsor mention with Amplitude lead-in follows.

topics.title: Sponsor: Amplitude product loop and new tools
topics.summary: John Cutler explains Amplitude’s expansion from analytics into experimentation and CDP, driven by supporting the full product loop and customer usage patterns. Lenny closes with a CTA to amplitude.com.

topics.title: Sponsor: Lenny’s Jobs talent marketplace
topics.summary: Lenny promotes the hiring marketplace for product and growth roles, describing the vetting process and how candidates can join anonymously. CTA to lenny’sjobs.com/talent.

topics.title: Emily’s career overview and MKT1 plug
topics.summary: Emily summarizes her path building B2B startup marketing functions and her current work advising and investing. She plugs MKT1, Market 1 Capital, and her website hub for resources.

topics.title: Common mistakes hiring early marketing roles
topics.summary: Emily explains why marketing hiring is confusing even for marketers and highlights a key mistake: hiring someone misaligned with what the startup needs most. She argues business model experience (PLG vs enterprise/top-down sales) matters more than industry/audience familiarity.

topics.title: Fuel vs engine: diagnosing constraints and examples
topics.summary: Emily details what counts as fuel (positioning, messaging, web copy, content assets) versus engine (channels, distribution, lifecycle systems, ops), noting many activities contain both. She gives heuristics to diagnose which side is broken and how that informs the first hire.

topics.title: Product marketing definition and three archetypes
topics.summary: Emily defines product marketing as understanding product, audience, and market to communicate the right things at the right time, often bridging fuel and engine. She introduces three common early marketing archetypes: product marketing, content/community, and growth/demand.

topics.title: Pie-shaped marketers and early-stage hiring approach
topics.summary: Emily recommends hiring generalists early—specifically "pie-shaped" marketers with depth in one area, proficiency in a second, and strategy across all. She notes product+growth or product+content combinations are more common than content+growth due to different skill profiles.

topics.title: Growth PM vs growth marketing in PLG
topics.summary: Emily distinguishes demand/growth marketing from product growth roles, especially in top-down sales businesses, and explains where they overlap in PLG. She emphasizes the marketing-to-product handoff (signup to in-product experience) and the need for clear collaboration to avoid disjointed user experiences.

topics.title: What to look for in first product marketer
topics.summary: Emily shares hiring signals: candidates should have experience early enough to avoid siloed roles, understand how to build foundations, and have a high quality bar. She warns against hiring only-big-company marketers for first marketing roles and stresses strong writing ability.

topics.title: When to hire first marketer and readiness checks
topics.summary: Emily suggests hiring around seed-to-Series A depending on model, generally after some evidence of product-market fit and when marketing can accelerate one-to-many growth. She recommends asking what the marketer would do immediately and whether product and positioning are stable enough to support scaling.

topics.title: Sponsor: Athletic Greens (AG1) read
topics.summary: Lenny shares his personal routine with AG1, highlights benefits, and gives the offer details (vitamin D supply and travel packs). CTA to athleticgreens.com/lenny.

topics.title: Brand marketing in B2B and team ownership
topics.summary: Emily explains how "brand marketing" maps to product marketing plus content/community and design collaboration in B2B. She describes how brand roles evolve at larger team sizes to ensure consistency, editing, and big cross-channel initiatives.

topics.title: Product vs marketing ownership and collaboration systems
topics.summary: Emily challenges the idea that PLG replaces marketing, arguing it often requires more marketing since sales is reduced. She discusses ownership boundaries (website vs in-product flows) and shares Asana’s DRI system—clear responsibility lists beyond titles—to improve product/marketing coordination on launches and experiences.
